content.question: The rate at which ants arrive at a picnic is modeled by the function <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="A, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in ants per minute and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. The graph of <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the figure above. How many ants arrive at the picnic during the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 30" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts
